Important Note about this Form:

Please contact the CCM team (curriculum_help@utk.edu) before submitting this form so that an administrator can determine if there is a more suitable form for the proposal.

This form is for items that need to appear in an upcoming agenda but are not handled by any other form. Informational items (e.g., reactivating an archived course) can be handled through this form. For Committee Reports, please use the "Committee Reports" form.

column35:
Directions to Propose Content Changes:

1. Copy and Paste the current content from the Catalog as it appears online into the field below. Do NOT make any edits to the text until step 4.

2. Click on Save (this will ensure that original content is saved).

3. After you have completed all required fields, Validate and Launch your proposal.

4. Apply and format the changes directly to the text.  Be sure to format the content exactly as it will appear online.

5. After you have completed all edits to the text, be sure to approve your proposal in the decisions tab on the right.

column121:
Instructions for Form - Read This First

For DEPARTMENT changes, chancellor's approval is required (via the provost's office), after which, the proposal will move through the normal approval process as an informational item. For DIVISION, COLLEGE, or SCHOOL changes, approval is required from the VP of academic affairs and student success, THEC, and then the BOT, after which the proposal will move through the normal approval process as an informational item.

For ALL academic unit requests, first contact the provostâ€™s office and attach the approval documentation to this Curriculog form. Consult section 4.7 in the Curricular Submission Guide for further information about required approval documents. Please fill out Revise Program forms and Revise Course forms for all accompanying programs and/or courses that will need updated as the result of moving, adding, or consolidating academic units.

column151:
Instructions for Subject Changes

Changing a subject code requires full approval. New subject codes will be temporarily available in Curriculog before full approval, and will only be permanently available after full approval.

  • A new subject code must be verified for use before it can be used for new courses. This is done by completing the New Prefix/Subject Code form. The Curriculum and Catalog Management team (CCM) will research the availability of subject codes, suggest alternatives if necessary, and create a new subject code in the system for use on course forms. 
  • Fill out Revise Course forms for equivalent courses (courses that switch from the old subject code to the new subject code).
  • Fill out Drop Course forms for courses that will no longer be active under either subject code.
  • Fill out Add Course forms for new courses to be active under the new subject code.
  • Include equivalent courses in this form's equivalency table and in each applicable Revise Course form.
  • If the course that is being dropped carries a Vol Core designation, the department must submit a proposal to the Vol Core Committee asking that the equivalent course carry the same designation. Approval is not automatic.
  • If the old course had attached fees, then the fees for the new course will need to be approved by the Office of Budget and Finance. Please contact the CCM or the Bursarâ€™s Office with any questions about these fees. Approval of fees is not automatic.
  • If cross-listed courses are included, all departments affected by the change must be informed so they may update their own courses. New course numbers for secondary cross-listed courses are NOT needed, however, both primary and secondary courses should be updated appropriately.

The Curriculum and Catalog Management team (CCM) will research the availability of subject codes, suggest alternatives if necessary, and create a new subject code in the system for use on course forms.

  • If the course that is being dropped carries a Vol Core designation, the department must submit a proposal to the Vol Core Committee asking that the equivalent course carry the same designation. Approval is not automatic.
  • If the old course had attached fees, then the fees for the new course will need to be approved by the Office of Budget and Finance. Please contact the CCM or the Bursarâ€™s Office with any questions about these fees. Approval of fees is not automatic.
  • If cross-listed courses are included, all departments affected by the change must be informed so they may update their own courses. New course numbers for secondary cross-listed courses are NOT needed, however, both primary and secondary courses should be updated appropriately.

column49: Career planning, job markets in the agricultural industry, and techniques to obtain employment, including recruitment/placement services, resume construction, personal interviewing, and job-offer evaluation/analysis.
column67: The Department of Agricultural and Resource Economics is streamlining course offerings to best align teaching resources with degree programs and concentrations. This course will be replaced by ALEC 300 Careers and Professional Development in all undergraduate majors and concentrations offered in Department of Agricultural and Resource Economics.
column68: AREC 310 was last offered in Fall 2021. Starting in Fall 2022 all AREC majors took ALEC 300 as a substitute for AREC 310. Due to this enrollment in ALEC 300 increased by 30 students per academic year.

column49: Architectural design as a creative process based on visual thinking and ideas related to space, technology, and/or place. Scope and definition of the built environment in relation to contemporary society, building industry, and allied design professions. Orientation to courses and programs of the school.

column64: Architecture major or interior architecture major.
column67: For years, the course was “Introduction to Architecture” required for both first year architecture and interior design students. In 1998, the Interior Design Program moved into the College of Architecture and Design. The course name was changed to “Introduction to the Built Environment” as an effort to be more inclusive for the interior architecture students. In 2017, the School of Interior Architecture created what is now IARC 101, which is required for the interior architecture students.  Thus, ARCH 101 now has only architecture students.

column49: Students will attend ARCH 101 classes with supplementary assignments and/or class meetings.
column67: (Name change is consistent with ARCH 101 proposal) Originally, this course was titled "Honors: Introduction to Architecture" but was modified to "Honors: Introduction to the Built Environment" to be inclusive of interior design (now interior architecture) when the program joined the college in 1998. In 2017, the interior architecture program created its own IARC 107 course. ARCH 107 now only instructs architecture students.

column49: This course provides students with an introduction to the use of plant materials in the built environment, drawing upon contemporary approaches to landscape architecture and sustainable landscape design. The course is structured to provide students with concrete working knowledge - identification and performative characteristics - of approximately 120 plants that are somewhat common in the southeast or across the United States with a particular emphasis on plants that are well-adapted to urban situations. In addition to plant identification, the course will provide students with a series of frameworks through which to consider how plants have been or could be utilized, as well as emerging ecological theories such as novel ecosystems.
column57: Students may not receive credit for both LAR 232 and LARN 232 or LAR 432.
column67: This course supports the proposed Landscape Architecture Minor.
column164: College of Architecture and Design - LAR - 232

column49: This course explores the changing identity of Nature across cultures and times in order to speculate about what the future of Nature might be in the 21st century. The course surveys a wide range of historical concepts of Nature globally as well as new ecological, cultural, scientific, and technological conditions that require new ways of thinking about what Nature has been and will become. Students will be introduced to examples of first, second, and third nature, urbanatural, and other productive hybrid conditions that have emerged in order to rethink preconceived notions of Nature and formulate new ways of thinking about the subject.
column67: Course supports Landscape Architecture Minor. Provides opportunity for undergraduate students to gain exposure to the field of landscape architecture and related topics of interest. Course will be proposed as future Vol Core course.
column164: College of Architecture and Design - LAR - 240

column45: Planetary Gardening: Towards a Sustainable Future
column49: This course surveys a wide range of strategies and tactics being deployed to increase the sustainability of life on earth in the 21st century. From geoengineering to guerrilla gardening, students will learn about ways that cultures and societies are attempting to adapt to, mitigate, and reverse the deleterious effects resulting primarily from development, industrialization, and anthropogenic climate change.
column57: Students may not receive credit for both LAR 241 and LARN 241
column67: Course supports Landscape Architecture Minor. Provides opportunity for undergraduate students to gain exposure to the field of landscape architecture and related topics of interest. Course will be proposed as future Vol Core course.
column164: College of Architecture and Design - LAR - 241

column49: This course is intended to provide students with an awareness and appreciation for contemporary landscape architecture. While the primary focus of the course will be from 1950 to the present, we will periodically reach farther back into history in order to better understand key historical precedent projects and designers that were or are influential to contemporary designers and projects. This course situates current practices through a survey of precedents, events and spatial developments across cultures and scales. In order to understand the projective discipline of landscape architecture, we must study how it has been informed, influenced and shifted over its relatively short existence.
column57: Students may not receive credit for both LAR 286 and LAR 487
column67: Course supports proposed Landscape Architecture Minor

column49: Faculty initiated professional elective in landscape architecture.

column45: Ecological Design: Theories and Methods I
column49: Surveys the evolving socio-ecological conditions resulting from urbanization, climate dynamics, evolving economies and technological innovation. Landscape architects around the world increasingly engage these complexities in the built environment to create new possibilities for the economic, social, and environmental performance of landscapes in public, private, and infrastructural territories. Will use contemporary projects as a basis for understanding multi-scalar design approaches, technical details, and maintenance regimes. Emphasis will be placed on built landscapes and living systems as integral parts of more dynamic, resilient, and sustainable approaches to landscape design, implementation, and management across scales from the site to the watershed.

column137: Graphic Design Studies Minor
column141:
Graphic Design Studies is open to students from any discipline across the University of Tennessee, Knoxville interested in enhancing their major field of study with an understanding of graphic design. Students will receive a broad introduction to concepts, processes, modes of visual communication, and the influence of design in today's world without the intensive, studio-driven experience of the major. The 3 required lecture-based core classes couple with a selection of classes from across several colleges that allow further focus within the minor.

Students must have a cumulative 2.5 GPA and be a declared major outside of the School of Design in order to undertake the minor. Application to the minor is available via the online minor form for the College of Architecture and Design.

Students must successfully complete the following requirements (15 hours).
column164: College of Architecture and Design - School of Design - Graphic Design Studies Minor

column67: The minor has been updated to align with the other minor in the School of Design; three online asynchronous core courses with two electives drawing from interdisciplinary options from across the university.

column69: Primary impact will sit within the School of Design. Financial support to fulfill faculty hires has the approval of Dean Young, College of Architecture and Desgin
column137: Industrial Design Studies Minor
column141:
Industrial Design Studies is open to students from any discipline across the University of Tennessee, Knoxville  interested in enhancing their major field of study with an understanding of industrial design. The core classes will provide students with a broad introduction to concepts, processes, human factors, and the influence of industrial design in today’s world. Electives offer options from across several colleges that allow further focus within the minor, including the option to take studio-intensive making classes from the School of Design.

Application to the minor is available via the online minor form for the College of Architecture and Design.

Students must successfully complete the following requirements (15 hours).
column164: College of Architecture and Design - School of Design - Industrial Design Studies Minor

column67: Opportunity for greater exposure to landscape architecture and related topics for undergraduate students at UT.
column68: All courses offered by units external to the school have provided approval for inclusion in the proposed minor. See attached memos.
column69: Costs associated with staffing new courses in landscape architecture. School has support of School of Landscape Architecture Director and Dean of the College of Architecture and Design to sustain these courses.
column137: Landscape Architecture Studies Minor
column141:
The Minor in Landscape Architecture Studies is open to students from any discipline across the University of Tennessee, Knoxville interested in enhancing their major field of study with a greater understanding of the practices being used in contemporary landscape architecture and design. Students will receive a broad introduction to key concepts, processes, and techniques, as well as the evolving role of landscape architecture and landscape design as they seek to engage global issues of sustainability, environmental justice, anthropogenic climate change, and more. The 3 required lecture-based core classes are coupled with a selection of classes from across several colleges that complement the focus within the minor.

Students must have a cumulative 2.5 GPA and be a declared major outside of the School of Landscape Architecture to undertake the minor. Application to the minor is available via the online minor form for the College of Architecture and Design.

Students must successfully complete the following requirements (15 hours).
column164: College of Architecture and Design - School of Landscape Architecture - Landscape Architecture Studies Minor

column49: Computational research is now a major part of the social sciences, including anthropology. This course combines lectures with practical tutorials in computational approaches using digital data on cultural change, from ancient to contemporary social media. Students are encouraged to bring a laptop, but no programming experience is required.
column67: The only change is to replace the words "big-data" with "computational", in both the course title and first senctence of the course description. This reflects developments in the field, and how practitioners now refer to these techniques.
column68:

column4: College of Arts and Sciences - Removing Writing-Emphasis Designation
column10:
On the recommendation of the CAS Curriculum Committee, the Dean’s Cabinet decided to remove the writing-emphasis designation from the CAS Catalog as a procedural error. The designation does not preclude earning a degree since it is not a program or college-wide requirement. Instead, many students confuse it with the WC Vol-Core requirement, resulting in their disappointment and frustration when they complete a writing-emphasis course but do not receive WC credit. Thus, to simplify the College’s curriculum and to clarify its connection with University Vol Core requirements, the College will remove the designation from the Catalog page. 

The attached file has the list of all Undergraduate Courses that will have the writing-emphasis designation removed. All departments and colleges with courses in the list have been notified, and any courses that CAS departments requested to have an additional line to replace the writing-emphasis designation have been processed as "UG Revise Course" proposals. Undergraduate courses also listed in the Graduate Catalog have been updated in "Grad Revise Course" proposals. The UG Curriculum Committee should review this proposal to accompany the revise course proposals that it will review in tandeum for Cycle 4.
column164: College of Arts and Sciences - Removing Writing-Emphasis Designation

column49: This course will focus on the importance of culture in our everyday lives and the ways in which culture influences communication processes. In today's era of rapid globalization, being able to communicate across cultures is imperative to one's ability to function in a diverse workplace, city, and world. Unique relational beliefs, perceptions, and norms profoundly affect communication and the goals of this class are to develop perspectives on the influence of culture on communication and to build skills for improving one's own intercultural interactions.
column64: Communication studies majors/minors or consent of instructor

The tuition students pay for this course will be directed to the College of Communication and Information, consistent with UTK's new budget model. No financial impacts on other units across campus are anticipated.
column164: College of Communication and Information - CMST - 415

column45: Fundamentals of Information Security and Cybersecurity
column49: Provides the conceptual, practical, and theoretical foundations of cybersecurity in the context of information and data life cycles. Topics include recognizing evolving vulnerabilities and internal and external security threats, attacks, and risks to information and data and mitigating them, information and data integrity, security architecture, and information and data security applications.
column67:
This will be one of three required courses for a new Concentration in the Bachelor of Science in Information Sciences. This course is being added to address a gap in our Bachelor of Science in Information Sciences (BSIS) program and meet the demands of our undergraduate students based on feedback we received from current and previous students. The course builds on the school’s strong programs and curriculum in Data, Information Management, and Analytics; User Experience Design; and 

Applied Data Analytics and User Experience. While one or two similar courses across campus (e.g., COSC 366) provide the conceptual, practical, and theoretical foundations of cybersecurity in the context of information and data life cycles, they tend to be more technical and require multiple prerequisites. This course complements cybersecurity courses and programs in units such as the College of Emerging and Collaborative Studies (CECS) and the Min H. Kao Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) by providing unique perspectives on cybersecurity in the context of information and data security and integrity.
column69: We will hire one non-tenure-track faculty member to start on August 1, 2024.
column164: College of Communication and Information - INSC - 312

column49: Data curation lifecycle models, including creation, selection and appraisal, ingest, storage, sharing, reuse, and preservation. Foundational principles in data curation. Examines ethical creation, curation, use, and reuse of data, including the issues of privacy, classification, governance, accountability, bias, and data labor.
column67: This course is being added to address an opportunity presented by our curriculum. SIS has strengths in data management and use with courses such as INSC 380 (Information Management in Organizations), INSC 486 (Data Analytics), and INSC 489 (Information Visualization). This course would build upon and add to the skills and knowledge developed through these courses by engaging students with advanced concepts and ethical issues relating to the lifecycle of data. This addresses a gap in the curriculum by presenting an alternative view of data – rather than focusing on how students can find, manage, and work with data. They will learn how they fit into the lifecycle of data to become more sophisticated and ethical users and stewards of data.  This course will be submitted as a possible elective in the interdisciplinary Data Science major.
column164: College of Communication and Information - INSC - 385

column49: The course offers students an opportunity to develop the necessary skills and knowledge for understanding, developing, evaluating, and implementing effective policies and governance frameworks for information and data in the context of cybersecurity. Information Security and Cybersecurity policy and governance topics include but are not limited to ethics, privacy, accountability, bias, provenance, defamation, confidential information, electronic communication, compliance, audit, and legal issues related to privacy and security.
column67:
This will be one of three required courses for a new Concentration in the Bachelor of Science in Information Sciences. This course is being added to address a gap in our Bachelor of Science in Information Sciences (BSIS) program and meet the demands of our undergraduate students based on feedback we received from current and previous students. The course builds on the school’s strong programs and curriculum in Data, Information Management, and Analytics; User Experience Design; and 

Applied Data Analytics and User Experience. It also builds on the foundations course (INSC 312) to offer students an opportunity to develop skills and knowledge for developing, evaluating, and implementing effective policies and governance frameworks for information, data, and cybersecurity. The course complements cybersecurity courses and programs in units such as the College of Emerging and Collaborative Studies (CECS) and the Min H. Kao Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) by providing unique perspectives on cybersecurity in the context of information and data security and integrity.
column69: We will hire one non-tenure-track faculty member to start on August 1, 2024.
column164: College of Communication and Information - INSC - 412

column49: Covers advanced topics and applications in information, data, and cybersecurity, and cybersecurity tools and controls (administrative, physical, and technical) necessary to safeguard information and data throughout their life cycles and to protect them from corruption, theft, or unauthorized access. Other topics include but are not limited to encryption/decryption, authentication, anonymity, information and data integrity, ethical hacking, and security and risk analysis.
column67:
This will be one of three required courses for a new Concentration in the Bachelor of Science in Information Sciences. This course is being added to address a gap in our Bachelor of Science in Information Sciences (BSIS) program and meet the demands of our undergraduate students based on feedback we received from current and previous students. The course builds on the school’s strong programs and curriculum in Data, Information Management, and Analytics; User Experience Design; and 

Applied Data Analytics and User Experience. The course is intended to cover advanced topics and techniques in information, data, and cybersecurity, and cybersecurity tools and controls necessary to safeguard information and data - something lacking from other courses in SIS and other programs. By building on the foundational concepts and policy and governance-related topics in their other courses in the concentration (INSC 312, 412, and others), students will gain a deeper understanding and knowledge of the advanced topics and techniques. This course complements cybersecurity courses and programs in units such as the College of Emerging and Collaborative Studies (CECS) and the Min H. Kao Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) by providing unique perspectives on cybersecurity in the context of information and data security and integrity.
column69: We will hire one non-tenure-track faculty member to start on August 1, 2024.

column67: The major provides an opportunity for transfer students who have earned an AA, AS, AFA, and AST degree from a TN community college to complete an online, asynchoronous degree from UT.  The college has had success with our interdisciplinary master's program and believes that this undergraduate degree would assist students who are interested in pursuing entry level careers in communication and information as well as those who are bound in their career and would like to complete a bachelor's degree meet their career objectives.   Please note: All JREM courses will be JMED courses.   We are working through the THEC approval process as well.  Aiming for approval by Fall 2024 to begin accepting students Spring 2025.
column68:
Minimal - 12 hours of electives are built into the major and would benefit other units who are offering distance education courses and have capacity to allow our students to take their courses.

Impact Audit Complete. No impact outside of CCI.
column69: There will be medium financial impact to CCI as we work with faculty to develop coursework in asynchoronous formats.

column138: Bachelor of Science in Communication and Information
column141: This online-only degree concentration is designed for students interested in developing or enhancing skills for communication careers.  Students will gain knowledge and skills in advertising, public relations, organizational communication, journalism and media and information sciences. It is specifically designed for transfer students. Students who have an Associate of Arts (A.A.), Associate of Fine Arts (A.F.T), Associate of Science (A.S.), or Associate of Science in Teaching degree (A.S.T). from a Tennessee accredited community college may complete the distance education Communication and Information bachelor's degree program.
column147:
• Understand and apply tools needed for success in dynamic communication landscapes 
  • Use theory and applied tools to navigate complex communication situations and build relationships in personal, group, and professional settings 
  • Develop and apply a diverse range of skills in the creation and interpretation of messages 
  • Produce content across multiple media platforms  
  • Apply analytic tools and processes to measure and understand audiences  
  • Understand, assess, and create digital content from a user-centered perspective 
  • Understand and communicate information ethics, policies, and laws

column137: Corporate Event Strategy, Promotion, and Production Minor
column141: The corporate event strategy, promotion, and production minor is open to undergraduate students interested in careers in corporate event management and is offered jointly through the College of Communication and Information and College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences. Students will develop and apply skills to effectively plan, execute, promote, and produce corporate events through hands-on training. The minor is open to students pursuing an undergraduate degree in any major at the University of Tennessee. The minor consists of 15 credit hours.
column147:
Program Learning Outcomes for the minor:

  1. Students will understand the strategic planning and execution of corporate events as well as how to engage media and other communication channels to promote them.
  2. Students will learn production techniques for event coverage as well as receive technical training for all aspects of corporate event execution.

column49: Media and Democracy is a course in media literacy and media effects. We take a fresh look at traditional, social, and digital media, with an emphasis on audience skills in understanding the messages we create, encounter, and evaluate. The course explores the crosscurrents of influence in several areas, including the role of public opinion and the media in the formation of democratic systems. Students will become better global citizens by being able to identify democratic operation differences between the U.S. and other countries. Class work also will address social class, ethnicity, gender, language, race, and religion as related to voting behavior, campaign strategies, and constituent services.

column49: This course engages students with all phases of audio-based storytelling in podcast form, including an overview of the genre and its place in news and creative media; the process for establishing and promoting a podcast with a specific audience in mind; as well as the process of podcast creation, including developing a story proposal, preproduction, conducting and recording interviews, collecting field and natural sound, and editing. Students will work with WUOT as part of the class.
column57: Students cannot receive credit for both JMED 465 and JMED 565.
column67:
With WUOT moving under CCI leadership, there is an opportunity to connect with the news and production team there to mutually-beneficial outcomes. Through conversations with the CCI Media Integration Committee, WUOT representatives have expressed an eager desire to work with JEM students. JEM students can benefit from working in partnership with a professional organization, and hopefully see their work land on their site or over the airways that they can then use when applying for jobs and internships.

Students in this course will be able to apply what they have learned in foundational JEM courses that teach aspects of reporting, understanding audiences, research and storytelling on a platform where students themselves regularly engage.

The JEM Undergraduate Committee believes this course should be cross-listed at the 500 level. Proposed graduate level syllabus is attached

column67: The School of Information Sciences has strong programs and curricula in Data, Information Management, and Analytics; User Experience Design; and Applied Data Analytics and User Experience.  Beyond a strategic reason to offer innovative programs in cutting-edge areas, an Information Security and Cybersecurity Concentration will address a gap in our Bachelor of Science in Information Sciences (BSIS) program and meet the demands of our undergraduate students based on feedback we received from current and previous students. The program will also complement other cybersecurity programs in units such as the College of Emerging and Collaborative Studies (CECS) and the Min H. Kao Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) by providing unique perspectives on cybersecurity in the context of information and data security and integrity. The demand for cybersecurity professionals who can develop, implement, and assess policies and procedures and run information and data security operations in 21st-century information and technology environments is growing. This unique cybersecurity program emphasizing information and data integrity and security will attract students interested in cybersecurity's social, technical, and human aspects, expanding options for UTK students to fill various job openings for cybersecurity professionals.

column137: Information Sciences Major, BS in Information Sciences â€“ Information Security and Cybersecurity Concentration
column138: Bachelor of Science in Information Sciences
column141:
The Information Security and Cybersecurity concentration is designed for students interested in careers in cybersecurity with an emphasis on information and data integrity and security. This concentration provides students with the knowledge and skills necessary to understand cybersecurity’s conceptual, practical, theoretical, and policy underpinnings in the context of information and data life cycles. The program will prepare students to apply their knowledge and skills to assess and recognize evolving security vulnerabilities, threats, attacks, and risks to information and data; implement effective policies and governance frameworks; and manage their implementations to mitigate the threats to ensure information and data integrity.

The program and courses in the curriculum will cover topics including information and data security applications, ethics, privacy, accountability, bias, copyright and intellectual property, defamation, confidential information, electronic communication, compliance, audit, legal issues related to privacy and security, and advanced topics such as cybersecurity tools and controls (administrative, physical, and technical), unauthorized access, encryption/decryption, authentication, anonymity, ethical hacking, and security and risk analysis.

column67: The Department of Child and Family Studies will be dissolved in fall 2024 in association with a significant restructuring of departments in CEHHS. As a result, the formerly constituted CFS programs at the undergraduate level will be moved. The ECE Undergraduate Programs (B-K and PK-3) have been moved to existing majors in TPTE. The CFS Undergraduate Program, "Community Outreach", will be moved to Counseling, Human Development, and Family Science (CHDFS). We will withdraw this request if the new major isn’t approved by THEC in time for the 2024-2025 catalog and we will reactivate the request once we have THEC approval for the new major. We are adding an identical program with a different name, so the courses these students will need will be available for them to take.
column68: There are no anticipated impacts on other units. The programs have been moved to TPTE and CHDFS and will continue to be taught in these departments. The curriculum for these programs will remain unchanged and thus will not impact other units.
column69: The programs will continue to use courses from other departments outside of CHDFS and TPTE, but because the curriculum is not changing these units will not experience any changes in financial impact.
column137: Child and Family Studies Major, BS in Health and Human Sciences â€“ Community Outreach Track
column138: Bachelor of Science in Health and Human Sciences
column141:
Program Policies and Progression Requirements

The department's major is designed for students whose educational and career goals are focused on studying and working with children and families within educational programs, community services, and other professional settings. The major is designed to accommodate the special interests or strengths of students to allow for flexibility and individualization. Students design a program of study in consultation with their advisor that includes a set of required courses, a complement of courses across the social sciences that support individual interests, and a 12-hour practicum that will complete their program of study. All students graduating with a child and family studies major will have in-depth knowledge about children and families, a broad integrative perspective, and means for application. Students must complete a total of 15 credits of Advanced Social Science coursework. Advanced Social Science courses may not be used to fulfill any other elective requirement. This required program of coursework meets the current eligibility requirements for certification as a "Certified Family Life Educator" (CFLE) through the National Council on Family Relations' approved program mechanism. Students interested in applying for provisional certification as a Family Life Educator are encouraged to pursue the steps indicated at ncfr.org.

Progression Requirements

Students are expected to know the criteria they must meet in order to progress into a practicum (CFS 470, CFS 472, CFS 480, or CFS 490) and to regularly monitor their progress in meeting these criteria. Students will not be allowed to progress into the practicum until these criteria are met. If students do not appear able to meet these criteria, they are encouraged to work closely with their advisor to plan an alternative educational program. Specific information on how to apply for the practicum is available from the student's advisor. Students must work closely with their advisor to ensure that they understand the requirements for progression and that they strictly follow the application process for the practicum experience of their choice.

College of Education, Health and Human Sciences Honors Program

Child and Family Studies majors have the opportunity to participate in the college's honors program. For eligibility and requirements, see College of Education, Health and Human Sciences Honors Program.

column67: The Department of Child and Family Studies will be dissolved in fall 2024 in association with a significant restructuring of departments in CEHHS. As a result, the formerly constituted CFS programs at the undergraduate level will be moved. The ECE Undergraduate Programs (B-K and PK-3) have been moved to existing majors in TPTE. The CFS Undergraduate Program in this proposal, "Community Outreach", will be moved to Counseling, Human Development, and Family Science (CHDFS). The curriculum and program requirements remain unchanged. A THEC proposal will be submitted for a new major for this program to be renamed as "Human Development and Family Science Major, BS". If the THEC proposal is approved in time for the 2024-2025 catalog, we will withdraw this current Revise Program proposal. These changes have been done in consultation with Dean Ellen McIntyre, Dr. Casey Barrio Minton (EPC IDH), and the CFS HDFS program faculty. These changes have also been done under the direction and guidance of Molly Sullivan with the UTK registrar's office.

The new department, CHDFS, will continue to teach courses that are required for the program.

column67: The Department of Child and Family Studies will be dissolved in fall 2024 in association with a significant restructuring of departments in CEHHS. As a result, the formerly constituted CFS programs at the undergraduate level will be moved. The ECE Undergraduate Programs (B-K and PK-3) have been moved to existing majors in TPTE. The CFS Undergraduate Program in this proposal, "Community Outreach", will be moved to Counseling, Human Development, and Family Science (CHDFS). Although this is an "Add Program" proposal, only the name has been revised (Child and Family Studies Major - Community Outreach) to Human Development and Family Science. The curriculum and program requirements remain unchanged. This change in name is necessary to reduce confusion with the former child and family studies programs and is consistent with the names of programs at peer and aspiration programs. A THEC proposal will be submitted for a new major. If the THEC proposal is not approved in time for the 2024-2025 catalog, we will retain the current name of the program for the upcoming catalog and change to the new major in 2025-2026. These changes have been done in consultation with Dean Ellen McIntyre, Dr. Casey Barrio Minton (EPC IDH), and the CFS HDFS program faculty. These changes have also been done under the direction and guidance of Molly Sullivan with the UTK registrar's office.

column49: Applications of descriptive and inferential statistics to problems in the educational, behavioral, and social sciences. Topics include data visualization, central tendency, variability, correlations, introduction to probability, sampling distributions, interval estimation, and univariate hypothesis testing. Statistical software is used to analyze data through hands-on activities.
column67:
More department - In August 2023, the ESM programs and faculty relocated to ELPS. The department change allows this course to relocate with them.

Course Number Change - This course is intended for first-year and sophomore students and the course number change is designed to reflect more accurately that it is an introductory course. This introductory course does not have any prerequisites.

Course Name Change - The course title will be changed from “Applied Statistical Concepts for Educators” to “Applied Statistical Concepts for Decision Makers”. The course content is directly applicable to problems in the educational, social, and behavioral sciences; but would prepare student to use statistics when making decisions in any setting. However, the current course title limits application solely to educational issues. The course title change will better reflect the nature of the course and be more attractive to all students.

column69: This course is currently being taught as part of the course load of existing faculty and graduate students, therefore, there is no financial request or demand on the department or college budget. This change may impact financially other units across campus, as it may be taken to meet QR requirement for Vol Core.

column137: Leadership Studies Minor
column141:
The Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies, through its Leadership Studies minor, offers a 12-hour curriculum of applied leadership education within the collegiate setting. This minor is open to students of every major. This experiential learning approach to leadership education (i.e., knowledge, disposition, and skill development) combines seminar, coached experiences, and lecture formats with mentoring and portfolio-based self-assessment, skill development and application in a capstone project – either self-directed or faculty guided experiential learning course.

Admission

Student applications to the minor are accepted throughout the year. The application packet includes a completed application (e.g., contact information, references, a list of leadership activities and involvements), and permission to access student records. An admissions committee comprised of ELPS faculty and instructors teaching in the program conduct a holistic review of the applications with the goal of creating a diverse cohort of students with demonstrated academic and experiential leadership success. Students are admitted into the minor based on the following criteria:

  • Academic potential as demonstrated by the GPA or leadership coursework;
  • Proven ability and preparation to lead a self-directed project;
  • Demonstrated passion for engaging in leadership, social change, and/or service;
  • Positional and/or non-positional leadership while in college;
  • Evidence of commitment to developing leadership potential; and
  • Unique contributions to the leadership learning cohort.

Minimally, students must be and remain in good standing with the university and Leadership Studies. The Leadership Studies minor must be declared and ELPS 351 or ELPS 352 passed with a B or better before beginning a self-directed leadership capstone project. Students must pass the ELPS 499 Proficiency course requirements to graduate.

Additional admission, timeline, curricular, and program contact information is available at: https://elps.utk.edu/leadership-studies-minor/.

column137: Kinesiology Major, BS in Kinesiology
column141:
The Kinesiology major prepares students for a variety of careers in health-related fitness and for graduate or professional study in various fields within kinesiology (exercise physiology, biomechanics, sport psychology, motor behavior, physical activity epidemiology, etc.), allied health professions (physical therapy, occupational therapy, physician assistant, chiropractic, athletic training, etc.) and medicine. Incoming freshmen ("first year students") can enter the Kinesiology major when they start at UT, or during their first two years. Transfer students can enter the Kinesiology major when they start at UT.

If a chosen career path will require graduate school, a student should know that planning for that starts now. Educational preparation as an undergraduate is an essential part of success later on. Many students arrive at the university with the goal to become a physician, physical therapist, or other health professional, but they have little knowledge of what the profession is really like or of its demands. Because competition is so intense in medicine and other health professions, students should become as familiar as possible with the career they are pursuing, including the additional education requirements and the minimum GPA and grades in specific courses to be competitive for admission to graduate study.

Major Requirements and Rules

Advising Transition

Academic advising for freshmen, sophomores, and new transfer students in the Kinesiology major occurs in the College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences Office of Advising & Student Services (BEC 332). A student will transition to KRSS Department advising after he/she completes the following U-track milestones:

  • Maintains a minimum cumulative UT GPA of 2.5 after a minimum of 60 hours of coursework.
  • Completes MATH 125* or MATH 141* or MATH 147*, KNS 200, CHEM 132* CHEM 133*, and BCMB 230. These are the uTrack milestones for the first four terms.
  • All of these courses must be completed with a C or better to remain in good standing and continue in the major.

At the end of each semester, staff of the CEHHS Office of Advising and Student Services will compile a list of students ready to change to departmental advising. Students will be emailed a letter with the name and contact information of their new department advisor. Students will then be responsible for scheduling a meeting with their new advisor to complete this transition.

Minimum Grades and Required GPA for Continuation in the Major

Students who do not earn a C or better in MATH 125* or MATH 141*, PHYS 221*, and KNS 332* will not be allowed to take KNS 422 - Biomechanics of Human Movement*. Students who do not earn a C or better in CHEM 122* and CHEM 123*, CHEM 132* and CHEM 133*, and BCMB 230 will not be allowed to take KNS 414 - Fitness Testing and Exercise Prescription or KNS 480 - Physiology of Exercise*.

All Kinesiology courses, Professional Electives, Department Electives, MATH 125* or MATH 141*, CHEM 122* and CHEM 123*, CHEM 132* and CHEM 133*, PHYS 221*, Professional Science Elective, and BCMB 230 (or any course(s) used as a substitute for these requirements) must all be passed with a C or better to graduate.

Kinesiology majors must maintain a cumulative UT GPA of 2.5 or better to register for any required 400-level Kinesiology courses (KNS 414, KNS 422*, and KNS 480*) and to graduate.

College of Education, Health and Human Sciences Honors Program

Kinesiology majors have the opportunity to participate in the college's honors program. For eligibility and requirements, see College of Education, Health and Human Sciences Honors Program.

column67: We propose the SCUBA minor as an opportunity for students in majors across the university to earn an immediately marketable skillset for their initial and future careers. Students completing the minor earn a professional certification, NAUI Divemaster, allowing them to work anywhere worldwide.  Based on the course roster makeup in the current and past semesters, the SCUBA minor would appeal to students across disciplines. Surveyed in Spring 2023, students throughout the 5 classes responded favorably in regard to their interest in a SCUBA minor (79 out of 87 total responses). This minor will consist of 14 credit hours. All required courses are currently offered in each fall and spring semester. Additionally, if designated as a minor, students wishing to complete the entire course sequence can use each course in their course program of study (CPOS) for financial aid purposes.

column137: Sport Management Major, BS in Recreation and Sport Management
column138: Bachelor of Science in Recreation and Sport Management
column141:
The Sport Management major prepares students interested in working in the sport industry. The program combines the sport management curriculum with a minor in business administration. The program concludes with a semester-long internship experience.

Major Requirements and Rules

Advising Transition

Academic advising for freshmen, sophomores, and transfer students in the Sport Management major occurs in the College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences (CEHHS) Office of Advising and Student Services (BEC 332). If you have not been advised by anyone in CEHHS Advising before, please visit their website for more information about scheduling an appointment with their office. The KRSS Advising Staff is not able to review a student's academic history if they are not currently a Sport Management major.

A student will transition from CEHHS Advising to KRSS Department Advising after he/she completes the following:

  • Maintains a minimum UT GPA of 2.5 after a minimum of 30 hours of coursework
  • Completion of RSM 250 with a grade of C or better
  • Successful completion of ENGL 101* and ENGL 102*, and one Quantitative Reasoning Elective*  

At the end of each semester, staff of the CEHHS Office of Advising and Student Services will compile a list of students ready to change to departmental advising. Students will be emailed an advising transition letter with the name and contact information of their new department advisor. Students will then be responsible for scheduling a meeting with their new advisor to complete this transition. Scheduling with KRSS Advisors should be done via email by contacting your new advisor directly.

Minimum Grades and Required GPA for Continuation in the Major

Any Recreation and Sport Management course taken must be passed with a minimum grade of C. A 2.5 GPA is required to register for RSM 290N*, RSM 390N*, and RSM 490N and to graduate.

College of Education, Health and Human Sciences Honors Program

Recreation and Sport Management majors have the opportunity to participate in the college's honors program. For eligibility and requirements, see College of Education, Health and Human Sciences Honors program.

Anecdotal evidence from students in advising sessions and class discussions suggest there would be interest in pursuing this option. The curriculum changes for the Sport Management major in 2020 allows for the reinstitution of the Sport Management minor. The Sport Management minor will have five required classes and one elective RSM class.

column137: Therapeutic Recreation Major, BS in Recreation and Sport Management
column138: Bachelor of Science in Recreation and Sport Management
column141:
Therapeutic Recreation major prepares students for employment in a variety of health care settings including programs for mental health and intellectual disabilities, physical rehabilitation centers, drug and alcohol treatment centers, and community-based programs. The program requires several out-of-class commitments, including overnight and weekend day commitments, and students should be prepared to complete background checks, drug screens, and other organizational requirements. Additionally, this program requires three field experiences that must be taken in sequence. The first two are part-time practicum experiences and the program concludes with a semester-long internship experience. Graduates fulfill the eligibility requirements for National Council for Therapeutic Recreation Certification.

Major Requirements and Rules

Advising Transition

Academic advising for freshmen, sophomores, and transfer students in the Therapeutic Recreation major occurs in the College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences (CEHHS) Office of Advising and Student Services (BEC 332). If you have not been advised by anyone in CEHHS Advising before, please visit their website for more information about scheduling an appointment with their office. The KRSS Advising Staff is not able to review a student's academic history if they are not currently a Therapeutic Recreation major.

A student will transition from CEHHS Advising to KRSS Department Advising after he/she completes the following:

  • Maintains a minimum UT GPA of 2.5 after a minimum of 30 hours of coursework
  • Completion of RSM 201 with a grade of C or better
  • Completion of ENGL 101* and ENGL 102*, and one Quantitative Reasoning course

At the end of each semester, staff of the CEHHS Office of Advising and Student Services will compile a list of students ready to change to departmental advising. Students will be emailed an advising transition letter with the name and contact information of their new department advisor. Students will then be responsible for scheduling a meeting with their new advisor to complete this transition. Scheduling with KRSS Advisors should be done via email by contacting your new advisor directly.

Minimum Grades and Required GPA for Continuation in the Major

Any Recreation and Sport Management course taken must be passed with a minimum grade of C. A 2.5 GPA is required to register for RSM 294N*, RSM 394N*, and RSM 494N and to graduate.

College of Education, Health and Human Sciences Honors Program

Sport Management majors have the opportunity to participate in the college's honors program. For eligibility and requirements, see College of Education, Health and Human Sciences Honors Program.

NUTR 311 –Physiological Biochemistry 

(RE) Prerequisite(s): BIOL160* or BCMB 230, Recommended Background CHEM 260. 

Formerly: NUTR 311 –Physiological Biochemistry 

(RE) Prerequisite(s): BIOL160* or BCMB 230 

Rationale: In the 2023-2024 catalog, we removed CHEM 260 as a prerequisite to provide students with more flexibility in their course selections. However, we are now proposing to add CHEM 260 as Recommended Background based on recent evidence we have gathered regarding student performance in both CHEM 260 and other NUTR courses. Our findings indicate that students who completed CHEM 260 before enrolling in NUTR 311 performed significantly better compared to those who took NUTR 311 without prior CHEM 260 experience. This disparity in performance had a noticeable impact on the overall learning experience for all students in the class and their progress through the course material.

NUTR 314 – Energy Metabolism and Metabolic Integration

(RE) Prerequisite(s): NUTR 311 or BCMB 401, and CHEM 260.

Formerly: NUTR 420 – Nutrition Research Design & Methods II (2)

(RE) Prerequisite(s): NUTR 311 or BCMB 401.

In the 2023-2024 catalog, we removed CHEM 260 as a prerequisite to provide students with more flexibility in their course selections. However, we are now proposing to reinstate it based on recent evidence we have gathered regarding student performance in both CHEM 260 and other NUTR courses. Our findings indicate that students who completed CHEM 260 before enrolling in NUTR 311 (a prerequisite for NUTR 314) performed significantly better compared to those who took NUTR 311 without prior CHEM 260 experience. This disparity in performance had a noticeable impact on the overall learning experience for all students in the class and their progress through the course material.

This prerequisite change was approved by the Nutrition faculty. No additional approvals are required for this change. The change is not substantive and does not need to be reported to SACSCOC

column67:
NUTR 321 – Vitamins in Human Nutrition

(RE) Prerequisite(s): NUTR 100* and BCMB 230. (RE) Corequisite(s): NUTR 322.

Formerly: NUTR 321 – Vitamins in Human Nutrition

(RE) Prerequisite(s): NUTR 100*. (RE) Corequisite(s): NUTR 322.

 

Supporting Information

Rationale: The inclusion of BCMB 230 (Fundamentals of human physiology, primarily focusing on cellular and organ-system interactions) as a prerequisite for NUTR 321 arises from routine curriculum evaluation and faculty input. These assessments have revealed that current students enrolled in NUTR 321 and NUTR 322 (both of which are co-requisites) lack fundamental knowledge in human physiology, particularly at the cellular and organ-system levels. This foundational understanding is essential for comprehending and mastering the course content. Notably, BCMB 230 is already a mandatory course for all nutrition majors. Therefore, we are proposing that students complete this course before taking NUTR 321 and NUTR 322. This adjustment aims to enhance student success in NUTR 321 and NUTR 322 by ensuring they have a solid foundation in human physiology.

column137: Nutrition Major, BS in Health and Human Sciences â€“ Biomedical Nutrition Science Concentration
column138: Bachelor of Science in Health and Human Sciences
column141:
The Nutrition major is designed for students interested in basic and applied sciences, and students are able to pursue one of three concentrations: the Biomedical Nutrition Science Concentration, the Community Nutrition Concentration, or the Dietetics Concentration. The Biomedical Nutrition Science Concentration of the Nutrition Major prepares students for graduate study in biological and health sciences or for health professional programs, such as pharmacy and medicine. This concentration also prepares students for careers as laboratory technicians, research assistants, technical consultants, and sales representatives in the biomedical and nutrition industries. Additional coursework may be is necessary to meet health professional program prerequisites and integration of this coursework should be coordinated closely with the academic advisor and/or pre-health advising as these requirements will vary by program. Students completing this track are not eligible to apply to any ACEND-accredited supervised practice programs.

Requirements for Transition to Upper Division

In order to graduate with a major in nutrition, regardless of concentration, students must earn a grade of C or better in every required nutrition course.

column67:
1- Rationale for changing the name: During the prior curricular revisions to the program, the word "Program" was inadvertently omitted. According to the Office of the University Registrar, this alteration necessitates prior approval from the CRC committee.

 

1- Rationale for adding English 255/257: The addition of ENGL 255 or ENGL 257(Honors) as an option to fulfill the WC requirement (along with ENGL 295 and 360) was suggested by the Assistant Director of Undergraduate Studies in the English Department after discussion about the intent for nutrition students to develop "communication and documentation skills sufficient for entry into professional practice," specifically by "demonstrating effective and professional oral and written communication and documentation." This course achieves those outcomes with a particular focus on communicating with a public audience, which is particularly relevant to nutrition professionals who work in pubic-facing positions (see attached document demonstrating the approval from the English Department).

column137: Nutrition Major, BS in Health and Human Sciences â€“ Biomedical Nutrition Science Concentration â€“ Five-Year BS/MS Program
column138: Bachelor of Science in Health and Human Sciences
column141:
For qualified students, the Department of Nutrition offers a 5-year BS/MS accelerated degree program with a major in Nutrition and a concentration in Biomedical Nutrition Science. Central to this program is that a qualified student may take up to 9 credit hours of approved graduate courses for their senior undergraduate electives and have them count toward both the BS degree and the MS degree. Students will be considered for conditional admission to the program by the end of their junior year of undergraduate study at UT. Students can choose from a project option or a thesis option, based on their original research. Those who choose the thesis option will begin working on their research project not later than the beginning of their senior year of undergraduate studies by enrolling in NUTR 493 and/or NUTR 499. For each student in the program, a graduate advisory committee composed of a minimum of three faculty members must be established before completion of Term 7. To be considered for conditional admission to the program:

  • A student must be a declared Nutrition major, Biomedical Nutrition Science Concentration, with a minimum GPA of 3.30, must have completed at least 15 credit hours of Nutrition courses, and must have completed at least 90 credit hours of the 120 credit hours of coursework required for the BS degree with a major in Nutrition.
  • A student must provide three letters of support from Nutrition faculty members serving on the graduate and undergraduate committees
  • A student must obtain a commitment from a Nutrition graduate research faculty member to serve as their graduate mentor-advisor (i.e., major professor) and as the chair of their graduate advisory committee.
  • The Department may consider other relevant factors such as an applicant's work experience and level of maturity before conditionally admitting a student to the BS/MS program. Conditional admission of a student into the 5-year BS/MS program must be approved by both the Department of Nutrition and the Graduate School. Students will be typically informed of the outcome of their application before they start their senior year of undergraduate study.

Any graduate course taken before satisfying all requirements for the BS degree must be approved by the student's graduate advisory committee, the Director of Graduate Studies, and the Graduate School. These graduate courses must be identified in advance in consultation with the undergraduate advisor and the graduate advisory committee.

A student that is conditionally admitted to the BS-MS program may complete up to 9 credit hours of graduate level coursework during the student's undergraduate study and apply those 9 credit hours to satisfy both the BS degree requirements and also the MS degree requirements, provided that these graduate credit hours were approved by both the Department and by the Graduate School.

The form "Nutrition Conditional Admission 5 Year BS-MS" is available from the Director of Graduate Studies and must be completed and signed by the undergraduate advisor, undergraduate coordinator, and graduate advisory committee by May 1 of their junior year. After review by the Department, the form will be signed by the Director of Graduate Studies and submitted to the Graduate School for approval and processing.

To receive graduate credit for the 9 credit hours listed on the Nutrition Conditional Admission Form and approved by their graduate advisory committee, and others granting approval by signing that form, the student must complete and submit the Senior Requesting Graduate Credit Form to the Graduate School. If the graduate courses are to be taken during different semesters, the student will need to submit this form per each relevant semester.

Conditional admission into the BS/MS program does not guarantee acceptance into either the Graduate School or the MS program. Students in the BS/MS program must submit an application for admission to the Office of Graduate Admissions and to the MS program during their senior year of undergraduate study for the term immediately following the completion of their undergraduate study, following the same procedures of all other student applicants. Students will be fully admitted to the MS program after they have been accepted both by the Graduate School and by the Nutrition Department. Students will not be eligible for graduate assistantships until they are enrolled as graduate-level students in the Graduate School.

column67:
These are predominantly house keeping items, reflecting minor revisions throughout the "showcase" for this concentration. Specific to terms 6-8, the revision to credit counts is to assure that students have the required 90 credits necessary at the end of their junior year that qualify them for applying for Senior Standing in Term 7, should they decide to pursue the 5-year accelerated BS/MS in Community Nutrition.

Term 1: We have removed 1 credit of unrestricted electives and NUTR 100 (3). We have added 3 credits of GC-US elective and CMST 240/247 (3 credits). Therefore, the overall credits in Term 1 have increased by 2 (totalling 16 credits).

Term 2: We removed the Expanded Perspectives Elective (3), as this requirement is met other required coursework. We replace these credits with 3 credits of Unrestricted Electives. No change to overall term credit hours.

Term 3: We removed 3 credits of Professional Electives and replaced these with 3 credits of Unrestricted Electives (increasing flexibility for students). We also added NUTR 100 to this term (from Term 1). No change to overall term credit hours.

Term 4: We replaced NUTR 200 (3) and NUTR 216 (3) with NUTR 220 (3) and NUTR 285 (3). No change to overall term credit hours.

Term 5: We replaced NUTR 220 (3) and NUTR 285 (3) with NUTR 200 (3) and NUTR 216 (3). In addition, we have revised the course name for NUTR 272, reflecting the course title revision brought forward on this same agenda. Finally, we have added an asterisk to the PUBH 320 entry, to reflect it's designation as a Volunteer Core course. No change to overall term credit hours.

Term 6: We replaced 3 credits of Professional Electives with 3 credits of Unrestricted Electives. We also added ENGL 255/257 as an option for completing the required WC coursework for Vol Core. Support from the offering department is included in supplementary materials. Finally, we added a statement alerting interested and eligible students to apply for the Accelerated Combined BS/MS Program during this term. No change to overall term credit hours.

Term 7: We replaced the PUBH elective (3) with Professional Elective (3) credits, and reduded the existing Professional Elective to 2 credits (for a total of 5 credits of Professional Electives). We added 3 credits of NUTR 493. This resulted in an overall reduction in term hours by one credit (now 15 credits).

Term 8: We removed GCUS elective (3) (now in Term 1) and added 2 additional NUTR 493. Therefore, the overall term credits dropped by one (now 14).

Footnote superscripts and content have been revised to reflect these showcase changes.

column137: Nutrition Major, BS in Health and Human Sciences â€“ Community Nutrition Concentration
column138: Bachelor of Science in Health and Human Sciences
column141: The Nutrition major is designed for students interested in basic, applied, and community nutrition sciences, and students are able to pursue one of three concentrations: The Biomedical Nutrition Science Concentration, the Community Nutrition Concentration, and the Dietetics Concentration. Each concentration includes a foundation in the basic sciences and introductory nutrition coursework which is built upon through advanced concentration-specific coursework, including nutrient metabolism, nutrition in disease prevention and treatment, elements of community nutrition, and interpretation of nutrition research literature. Students pursuing the Community Nutrition Concentration are trained in competencies needed to become a Certified Health Education Specialist (CHES) and to work in the community in a variety of roles, such as nutrition educators, WIC nutritionists, health and wellness coaches, and worksite wellness program coordinators, and in a variety of settings, such as public health departments, community agencies, and Extension programs. Individuals with CHES certifications are commonly employed in healthcare, government, university, business, community/non-profit, and K-12 education settings. For qualified students, the Department of Nutrition offers a 5-year BS/MS accelerated degree program with a major in Nutrition and a concentration in Community Nutrition. Interested students should see the section of the catalog specific to this program or see the Nutrition program information in the Graduate Catalog. This can lead to the Public Health Minor, but the student must declare it.

column138: Bachelor of Science in Health and Human Sciences
column141:
For qualified students, the Department of Nutrition offers a 5-year BS/MS accelerated degree program with a major in Nutrition and a concentration in Community Nutrition. Central to this program is that a qualified student may take up to 9 credit hours of approved graduate courses for their senior undergraduate electives and have them count toward both the BS degree and the MS degree. Students will be considered for conditional admission to the program by the end of their junior year of undergraduate study at UT. Students can choose from a project option or a course-only, no comprehensive exam option. Those who choose the project option will begin working on their project not later than Term 6 of undergraduate studies by enrolling in NUTR 493 with Public Health Nutrition faculty. For each student in the program, a graduate advisory committee composed of a minimum of three faculty members must be established before completion of Term 7. To be considered for conditional admission to the program. This can lead to the Public Health Minor, but the student must declare it.

  • A student must be a declared Nutrition major, Community Nutrition Concentration, with a minimum GPA of 3.30, must have completed at least 15 credit hours of Nutrition courses, and must have completed at least 90 credit hours of the 120 credit hours of coursework required for the BS degree with a major in Nutrition.
  • A student must provide three letters of support from three Community Nutrition faculty members.
  • A student must obtain a commitment from a Nutrition graduate research faculty member to serve as their graduate mentor-advisor (i.e., major professor) and as the chair of their graduate advisory committee.
  • The Department may consider other relevant factors such as an applicant's work experience before conditionally admitting a student to the BS/MS accelerated degree program. Conditional admission of a student into the 5-year BS/MS accelerated degree program must be approved by both the Department of Nutrition and the Graduate School. Students will be typically informed of the outcome of their application before they start their senior year of undergraduate study.

Any graduate course taken before satisfying all requirements for the BS degree must be approved by the student's graduate advisory committee, the Director of the Program in Public Health Nutrition, the Department Director of Graduate Studies, and the Graduate School. These graduate courses must be identified in advance in consultation with the undergraduate advisor and the graduate advisory committee.

A student that is conditionally admitted to the BS-MS accelerated degree program may complete up to 9 credit hours of graduate level coursework during the student's undergraduate study and apply those 9 credit hours to satisfy both the BS degree requirements and also the MS degree requirements, provided that these graduate credit hours were approved by both the Department and by the Graduate School.

The form "Nutrition Conditional Admission 5 Year BS-MS" is available from the Director of Graduate Studies and must be completed and signed by the undergraduate advisor, undergraduate coordinator, and graduate advisory committee by May 1st of their junior year. After review by the Department, the form will be signed by the Director of Graduate Studies and submitted to the Graduate School for approval and processing.

To receive graduate credit for the 9 credit hours listed on the Nutrition Conditional Admission Form and approved by their graduate advisory committee, and others granting approval by signing that form, the student must complete and submit the Senior Requesting Graduate Credit Form to the Graduate School. If the graduate courses are to be taken during different semesters, the student will need to submit this form per each relevant semester.

Conditional admission into the BS/MS accelerated degree program does not guarantee acceptance into either the Graduate School or the MS program. Students in the BS/MS accelerated degree program must submit an application for admission to the Office of Graduate Admissions and to the MS program during their senior year of undergraduate study for the fall term immediately following the completion of their undergraduate study, following the same procedures of all other student applicants. Students will be fully admitted to the MS program after they have been accepted both by the Graduate School and by the Nutrition Department. Students will not be eligible for graduate assistantships until they are enrolled as graduate-level students in the Graduate School.

column41: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
column67:
Rationale for adding ENGL 255/257 to the list of course options: The addition of ENGL 255 or ENGL 257(Honors) as an option to fulfill the WC requirement (along with ENGL 295 and 360) was suggested by the Assistant Director of Undergraduate Studies in the English Department after discussion about the intent for nutrition students to develop "communication and documentation skills sufficient for entry into professional practice," specifically by "demonstrating effective and professional oral and written communication and documentation." This course achieves those outcomes with a particular focus on communicating with a public audience, which is particularly relevant to nutrition professionals who work in pubic-facing positions (see attached document demonstrating the approval from the English Department).

 

Rationale for removing FDSC 415: The decision to remove FDSC 415 from the dietetics curriculum as an option to fulfill the “food science” required element is supported by the Department of Food Science. This decision aims to ensure that the available course options optimally address the essential learning elements for aspiring dietetics professionals. The low enrollment of dietetic students in FDSC 415, coupled with its lack of coverage of fundamental food science principles compared to other available courses, further justifies its exclusion. The recent addition of HTM 101 as an alternative option enhances our capacity to streamline and improve the curriculum by eliminating FDSC 415 as a choice (see attached document demonstrating the approval from the Food Science Department).

 

 

Rationale for adding NUTR 216 or AGNR 180 on the list with an asterisk denoting fulfillment of the GCI requirement.: Requiring dietetics students to choose between NUTR 216 and AGNR 180 to fulfill the “Global Citizenship – International” VolCore requirement better fulfills both the “global nutrition” and “environmental sustainability” required elements of the accredited undergraduate dietetics curriculum. Currently, these required elements are found minimally in other coursework, and this change would provide a better exposure to these required elements of the dietetics curriculum.

 

Rationale for Substituting "KNS 350" with the option "KNS 250, KNS 350, or NUTR 200: Incorporating KNS 250 and NUTR 200 as alternatives, in addition to KNS 350, for the physical activity course in the dietetics undergraduate curriculum offers students a broader range of choices. Notably, the inclusion of KNS 250 enhances the synergy between the Nutrition-Dietetics major and the Nutrition and Physical Activity for Health minor. Unlike the previous scenario where only KNS 350 was available, the expanded options now fulfill the necessary physical activity component in the curriculum. Detailed discussions in email threads support the rationale behind including both courses (see attached document demonstrating the approval from the Kinesiology Department).
